topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Installation Prerequisites

li.p: The Cinder block storage backend must be configured to use VSA, 3Par, or Ceph.

The system running the installer needs to have Python 2.7. Most modern operating systems include this as part of their base toolkit. This document is geared toward a Linux operating system, but this does not preclude the installer from running on other operating systems with appropriate modifications to the command-line statements.
If you did not create the Service Network immediately after installing HP Helion OpenStack, you must do so now.
For Windows and .NET support, due to licensing requirements, you must create and deploy your own Windows and SQL Server images. This requires the following:

ul.li: Windows images must be created in a MacOS or Linux environment.
You must have a Windows Server 2012 Enterprise (non-evaluation) image.
A volume license for Windows Server 2012 Enterprise is strongly recommended.
Additional tools (VirtIO and Virtual Box) are also required. See Building and Deploying Windows DEA and SQL Server Express Images for more information.

section.title: Gather Information
section.p: You will need the following information:

dlentry.dd: IP address of the HPE Helion OpenStack Deployer.
The OpenStack username of a cloud admin that has rights to perform a service update for the selected service.
The OpenStack password of a cloud admin that has rights to perform a service update for the selected service.

body.note: All of the following procedures are performed on the HPE Helion OpenStack Deployer. SSH to the Deployer before attempting any of these procedures.
body.section: Create the clouds.yaml Configuration FileThe installer retrieves configuration information from a configuration file located at /.config/openstack/clouds.yaml Each service has its own section within this file where configuration information is stored.This file must contain at least the Platform Configuration information before the HDPI can be installed.

section.title: Set Proxy Shell Variables
section.p: If your network uses a proxy, it may be necessary to set the https_proxy and http_proxy shell variables.

ol.li:
If your network uses a proxy, you must define the proxy exclusion list (no_proxy)
Source the keystone RC file.source keystone.osrc
Get the Keystone public endpoint IP addressKEYSTONE_IP_PUBLIC=$(openstack endpoint list | grep keystone | grep public | grep -Eo '[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}') echo 'KEYSTONE PUBLIC IP: ' $KEYSTONE_IP_PUBLIC or fully-qualified domain name, depending on your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment.id=$(openstack endpoint list | grep identity | cut -d "|" -f2 | tr -d " ")openstack endpoint show $id | grep publicurl | cut -d "|" -f3 | cut -d "/" -f3 | cut -d ":" -f1
Get the Keystone internal endpoint IP address. KEYSTONE_IP_INTERNAL=$(openstack endpoint list | grep keystone | grep internal | grep -Eo '[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}') echo 'KEYSTONE INTERNAL IP: ' $KEYSTONE_IP_INTERNAL or fully-qualified domain name, depending on your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment.id=$(openstack endpoint list | grep identity | cut -d "|" -f2 | tr -d " ")openstack endpoint show $id | grep internalurl | cut -d "|" -f3 | cut -d "/" -f3 | cut -d ":" -f1
Set the IP address values for no_proxy. Ensure that each and every Keystone AUTH_URL IP is included in the no-proxy list.export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,$KEYSTONE_IP_PUBLIC,$KEYSTONE_IP_INTERNAL

If your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment is behind a firewall, verify that the Sherpa proxy shell variables have been set. If these variables have not been set, either set them or follow the offline installation instructions to acquire the packages without using the Sherpa service.
Source the Keystone RC file. source keystone.osrc

Verify access to the Keystone public endpoint: KEYSTONE_URL_PUBLIC=`openstack endpoint list | grep keystone | grep public | grep -Eo '(http|https)://{1}\S+'` wget -t3 --timeout=5 -O/dev/null -q $KEYSTONE_URL_PUBLIC && echo exists OK || echo ERROR cannot reach $KEYSTONE_URL_PUBLIC

Verify access to the public Sherpa endpoint:SHERPA_URL_PUBLIC=`openstack endpoint list | grep sherpa | grep public | grep -Eo '(http|https)://{1}\S+' | sed -e 's/v1$//'` wget -t3 --timeout=5 -O/dev/null -q $SHERPA_URL_PUBLIC && echo exists OK || echo ERROR cannot reach $SHERPA_URL_PUBLIC
